firstChapter.htmlHeader: Learning disabilities: Summary
firstChapter.htmlStringContent:
• Definitions of learning disability generally encompass three core components:
    • Lower intellectual ability (usually an IQ of less than 70).
    • Significant impairment of social or adaptive functioning.
    • Onset in childhood.
  • People with milder learning disabilities may be able to live independently and care for themselves, manage everyday tasks, work in paid employment, communicate their needs and wishes, have some language skills, and may have additional needs that are not clear to people who do not know them well.
  • People with more severe learning disabilities are more likely to need support with daily activities such as dressing, washing, food preparation, and keeping themselves safe, have limited or no verbal communication skills or understanding of others, need support with mobility, have complex health needs and sensory impairments.
  • Risk factors for a learning disability include:
    • Some chromosomal and genetic anomalies — such as Down's syndrome, William's syndrome, Rhett syndrome, fragile X syndrome.
    • Some non-genetic congenital malformations — such as some types of spina bifida, hydrocephalus, microcephaly.
    • Prenatal exposures— including alcohol, sodium valproate, congenital rubella infection, zika virus.
    • Birth complications resulting in hypoxic brain injury/cerebral palsy.
    • Extreme prematurity (usually <33 weeks' gestation).
    • Childhood illness —such as meningitis, encephalitis, measles.
    • Childhood brain injury caused by accident/physical abuse.
    • Childhood neglect and/or lack of stimulation in early life.
  • Learning disability is associated with:
    • 'Behaviour that challenges'  (i.e is a challenge to services, family members, or carers). 
    • Physical health complications — around 50% people with learning disabilities have a comorbid physical health condition. 
    • Mental health problems — in the UK, mental health problems are experienced by up to 40% of adults and up to 36% of children and young people with learning disabilities. 
    • Social inequality.
    • Premature death.
  • When managing a person with a suspected/confirmed learning disability, their capacity to make decisions for themselves should be assessed on a decision-by-decision basis throughout assessment, care, and treatment.
    • Parents, carers, and/or care workers, or healthcare professional/social care practitioners who know the person well may be involved where appropriate.
  • If a learning disability is suspected, the person should be offered a referral to the local learning disability support team for confirmation of the diagnosis and general management.
  • People with a confirmed learning disability should be offered an annual health check in primary care that focuses on general health and also conditions that are more common in people with a learning disability. Those with a specific syndrome underlying their learning disability will also require assessment for other conditions associated with the syndrome.
  • People with a learning disability who present with 'behaviour that challenges' should be assessed by a professional with expertise in learning disabilities and be provided with a behavioural support plan.
    • Where a behavioural support plan is ineffective, or the person has more complex needs, referral to further support and intervention services may be necessary. 
  • A mental health problem should be considered if a person with learning disabilities shows any changes in behaviour such as loss of skills or needing more prompting to use skills, social withdrawal, irritability, avoidance, agitation, and/or loss of interest in activities they usually enjoy. 
    • If a person with a learning disability has a suspected mental health problem, an assessment should be carried out by a mental health professional with expertise in learning disabilities.
    • Where serious mental illness or dementia are suspected, the person should be offered a direct referral to a psychiatrist with expertise in assessing and treating mental health problems in people with learning disabilities.
    • The person should be offered interventions in-line with the relevant guidelines for their diagnosed mental health condition. The nature, content, and delivery of any interventions should be adjusted to take into account the impact of the person's learning disability.
